content.rendered:
It’s hard to believe all of the changes that have come to Northwest Arkansas since my family moved here in 1965. I, myself, being born in 1966 don’t remember anything of it until the early 70’s. Little that I remember is still the same. Most of the buildings in what used to be the center of town have been replaced, with the exception of “The Old Post Office” and a few shops. And what used to be a shop is now a bank.

I think part of what makes this area so unique is the strong presence of the faith that has been handed down from previous generations. And, while not all churches continue to grow, there are a few that thrive and flourish.

No, Northwest Arkansas doesn’t have the beauty of the Rocky Mountains, and you won’t find the beauty of a California sunrise, but it does have it’s own beauty and charm, along with it’s southern hospitality. And, while some of the major cities along the coast have lost some of their charm, it is not so with what I call home.

While it’s not quite the same as the place I grew up in, Northwest Arkansas still has it’s charms. For the most part, the people are still friendly — still willing to lend a hand. And you don’t have to look long to find a good church home.

No, it’s not California or New York, but I think that’s a good thing. If you move here, I hope you enjoy it. I hope you call this area home. But wherever you find yourself, remember that it’s family that makes a home.
